AN ORDlN ANCE for the regu! .tion of the own


ers, riders, and drivers Of carriages, wagons,


carts, drays, and horses, within the Borough of


Wilmington


Sic. 1. BE ii ordainedJy The Burgesses and Bo-
rough Council of Tie Borough Of Wilmington,
That from and after the passing of this ordinance,
all and every the drivers OF driver of all stages,
coaches, wagons, carts, drays, and other car
rages of pleasure or burthen, driving and passing
in and through the streets, lanes, or alleys OF this
Borough, shall keep on that side of the street,
lane alley on his or their right hands, respect
lively, in the passing direction; and if any driver
of any such carriage, wagon, cart or dray, shall
drive the same in the middle of the street, lane
CT alley, or on the left hand side Of the same, so
as TO prevent or obstruct another carriage from
passing along said street. every driver so Offend
ing shall forfeit and pay for every such offence,
sum not exceeding five dollars, nor less than one
dollar to be recovered with costs, before either
of the Burgesses, in the same manner as debts
under forty shillings are by law recoverable, one
moicty whereof shall be for the use of the person
suing for the game, and the other moiety shall be
for the use Of the Borough.


SIT. 2. Ind be 1t further ordained, That if
any driver Of any such carriage, or if any person


riding upon any horse mare or gelding, shall per-
nit or suffer the beast beasts he shall so drive
or ride, to so in gallop or other immoderate
gait, or shall engage in running or racing in any
manner with the driver or rider of any other car
riage, horse, mare or gelding, within any of the
streets, lanes or alleys of this Borough, every
person SO oitndng, shall forfeit'and pay for eve
" such offence, sum not exceeding Five dol
lars nor less than one dollar, to be recovered
with costs, by any person, in the manner and for
tile uses herein before mentioned.


I SEC 8. Ind be Hftrther ordained, That if any
person shall wilfully permit or suffer any horse.
mare or gcdng TO go at large through any of
/ the streets. lanes Or alleys ofths borough, every
person so offending shall forfeit and pay for eve.
~ such offence, the sum of one dollar, to be re-
covered with costs, by any person, in the man
ner and for the uses herein before mentioned.


SEC. 4. .4ad. be ii further ordained, That the
J, Ordinance entitled 'sAn Ordinance to prevent
the accidents and dangers that may happen by
peoples driving their teams out of walk faster


than is herein specified, and persons playing at
long bullets or any other game whereby there
may lie damage sustained" passed OIL the thirty
first day of August in the year OF our LORD one
thousand seven hundred and ffty-one, be, and
the same is hereby repealed, made null and void.


Passed at the Town Hall--April z, 1897.
JAMES BROBSON, First Burgess.
(Attcst) ]. P. FAIRLAMB,


Clerk ofNe Borough Council
ORDINANCE,

WHEN the first spark of desire after Con ari-
scs in thy soul; cherish it with all thy care, give
all thv heart into it: it is nothing less than q
touch of the Divine loadstone, that is to draw
thee out of the vanity of time, into the riches of
eternity. Get up, therefore, and follow it as
gladly, as the wise men Of the east followed the
star from Heaven that appeared 10 them. Ii
will do for thee rs the star did for thcm it win
lead thee to the birth of Jesus, (not in stable
at Bethlehem, in Judea,) but to the birth ol
Jesus, in the dark centre Of thy own fallen soul.

The brie Confucius, captain Riley, arriv
ed at New York, in thirty five days from
Lisbon. Captain r. furnishes single num-
ber of the Portuguese" OF the 27th OF Feb
ruarv. 1t is chiefly filled with the proceed
ings of the Cortes, which do not, on a curso-
nv examination, appear to be OF much inter-
est.


The paper contains the copy OF conven-
ton. STIMULATING certain arrangements Tor the
maintenance of the British forces in Portugal,
which was entered into in London on the 18TH
January, by the Portuguese ambassador and
Mr.. Canning, on tive part ct their respective
governments. BY tins convention tue Erlt
sh troops are to be maintained while IN For-
tugal, at the cxpence of this government,


General Clinton arrived at Coimbra on thc
nineteenth Of February. The 23d regiment
of British infantry had come IN three feSl-
ments of infantry, a battalion OF morse, ana
the cavalry Of hussars had arrived on the
fiftecth Another regiment was expected
on the following day.


The two Chambers of the Cortes were IN
session. A committee was appointed by the
Peers, to draw up an address TO the throhe'
requesting that pardons might be offered to
certain descriptions of rebels. The Count
Villa Flor was present, and OF course haa
absented himself from the army.


Private letters from Lisbon to the first OF
March, received by the Confucius, state po-
litical affairs were far from being settled, al
though 10 new occurrences of Importance
had transpred. The Anti ConstitutionaIiSts,
if nut down in one section Of the country,
suddenly appeared in other places III such
numbers and with such means, as could not
be accounted for on any other ground, than
that they were reinforced and furnished with
money by Spain or some other foreign pow
er. There was no doubt that large MAJOR
ity of the ignorant lower classes OF the For
tuguese population were taught to believe
that that they must oppose government which
would operate against the interests OF their
long established religion and habits. One
letter expresses belief that war must yet
be carried into Spsin. This was also the
opinion of the American consul, as we are IN
formed by capt. Riley. Captain X. under
stood that an engagement had taken plas e
between party of the royalists and one OF
the constitutionaiists, about the last OF teh-
ruary, near the frontiers Of Spain. III which
the former were again defeated.

The ARIEL is intended 10 be an interesting
and agreeable companion for tho Ladies, devot-
ed to Literature and the Arts containing sy-
nopsis of all that is passing in the polite, the
fashionable, and the literary world, with sum
mary of news. Original Essays, choice Tales,
select pieces Of Poctry sketches of female char
lctcr, and other pleasing matter will occupy its
pages.


The Editor promises that no labor or expense
| will be spared to make it cheap and valuable
yster in the hands ofhterary ladies'. Measures
have been taken to secure the best periodicals OF
the day, from which extracts, calculated to i'm
move the female mind, Will be freely taken He
is determined to make it acceptable TO the La
dies. the uncommonly low price at which it is
published one DOllar yearly, must place it with
in every ones reach.


sufficient patronage is extended, the Ariel

SHAKESPEARE.--A dramatic process
sion is intended to be given on the next ami
versary OF the birth day of Shakespeare---
He was born April 23d, 1864. Grand pre-
para.ions are now making by the Shakes

peare society Of Stratford- on Avon, towards
celebration of the day and handsome
subscription has already been entered into
to defray incidental expences.

A lamp has been invented in England
which burns without a wick and is supplied
with oil, A capillary, or very small tube, is
supported perpendicularly in the oil, and on
being lighted, will burn with perfect rcgu-
larity until exhausted.

We have not, for long time. had spring
which promises as fruitful a year as the pre-
sent; and if the saying of our old men hold
good, the last cold winter is security that our
promises of rich harvest will not be ami
hilated by untimely frost According to a
crcditable old inliabitant of Saltzburgh it is
now near sixty years since the peach trees
were in bloom on the tenth of April.

The following particulars of the devasta-

in the Canary Islands. we obtain from a late
Havana paper. It is copied from private
lctter.-Three vessels were lost at Santa
Cruz, with three men. On shore, many
houses were inundated. At Candelaria two
houses were destroyed with bridge, pri-
son. the castle, with eight meu. At Guim-
ar, or six persons, eight houses and farm
houses in the vicinity. At La Guancha, $50
houses, with nearly all the inhabitants. At
Oratava l02 men, women and children, and
5s7 domestic animals, brsides rs houses ru-
ined and IA destroyed.

full articles.headline: ORDINANCE,
full articles.article:
AN ORDlN ANCE for the regu! .tion of the own


ers, riders, and drivers Of carriages, wagons,


carts, drays, and horses, within the Borough of


Wilmington


Sic. 1. BE ii ordainedJy The Burgesses and Bo-
rough Council of Tie Borough Of Wilmington,
That from and after the passing of this ordinance,
all and every the drivers OF driver of all stages,
coaches, wagons, carts, drays, and other car
rages of pleasure or burthen, driving and passing
in and through the streets, lanes, or alleys OF this
Borough, shall keep on that side of the street,
lane alley on his or their right hands, respect
lively, in the passing direction; and if any driver
of any such carriage, wagon, cart or dray, shall
drive the same in the middle of the street, lane
CT alley, or on the left hand side Of the same, so
as TO prevent or obstruct another carriage from
passing along said street. every driver so Offend
ing shall forfeit and pay for every such offence,
sum not exceeding five dollars, nor less than one
dollar to be recovered with costs, before either
of the Burgesses, in the same manner as debts
under forty shillings are by law recoverable, one
moicty whereof shall be for the use of the person
suing for the game, and the other moiety shall be
for the use Of the Borough.


SIT. 2. Ind be 1t further ordained, That if
any driver Of any such carriage, or if any person


riding upon any horse mare or gelding, shall per-
nit or suffer the beast beasts he shall so drive
or ride, to so in gallop or other immoderate
gait, or shall engage in running or racing in any
manner with the driver or rider of any other car
riage, horse, mare or gelding, within any of the
streets, lanes or alleys of this Borough, every
person SO oitndng, shall forfeit'and pay for eve
" such offence, sum not exceeding Five dol
lars nor less than one dollar, to be recovered
with costs, by any person, in the manner and for
tile uses herein before mentioned.


I SEC 8. Ind be Hftrther ordained, That if any
person shall wilfully permit or suffer any horse.
mare or gcdng TO go at large through any of
/ the streets. lanes Or alleys ofths borough, every
person so offending shall forfeit and pay for eve.
~ such offence, the sum of one dollar, to be re-
covered with costs, by any person, in the man
ner and for the uses herein before mentioned.


SEC. 4. .4ad. be ii further ordained, That the
J, Ordinance entitled 'sAn Ordinance to prevent
the accidents and dangers that may happen by
peoples driving their teams out of walk faster


than is herein specified, and persons playing at
long bullets or any other game whereby there
may lie damage sustained" passed OIL the thirty
first day of August in the year OF our LORD one
thousand seven hundred and ffty-one, be, and
the same is hereby repealed, made null and void.


Passed at the Town Hall--April z, 1897.
JAMES BROBSON, First Burgess.
(Attcst) ]. P. FAIRLAMB,


Clerk ofNe Borough Council

full articles.headline: BEAUTIFUL. EXTRACT.
full articles.article:
WHEN the first spark of desire after Con ari-
scs in thy soul; cherish it with all thy care, give
all thv heart into it: it is nothing less than q
touch of the Divine loadstone, that is to draw
thee out of the vanity of time, into the riches of
eternity. Get up, therefore, and follow it as
gladly, as the wise men Of the east followed the
star from Heaven that appeared 10 them. Ii
will do for thee rs the star did for thcm it win
lead thee to the birth of Jesus, (not in stable
at Bethlehem, in Judea,) but to the birth ol
Jesus, in the dark centre Of thy own fallen soul.

full articles.headline: LATEST FROM PORTUGAL
full articles.article:
The brie Confucius, captain Riley, arriv
ed at New York, in thirty five days from
Lisbon. Captain r. furnishes single num-
ber of the Portuguese" OF the 27th OF Feb
ruarv. 1t is chiefly filled with the proceed
ings of the Cortes, which do not, on a curso-
nv examination, appear to be OF much inter-
est.


The paper contains the copy OF conven-
ton. STIMULATING certain arrangements Tor the
maintenance of the British forces in Portugal,
which was entered into in London on the 18TH
January, by the Portuguese ambassador and
Mr.. Canning, on tive part ct their respective
governments. BY tins convention tue Erlt
sh troops are to be maintained while IN For-
tugal, at the cxpence of this government,


General Clinton arrived at Coimbra on thc
nineteenth Of February. The 23d regiment
of British infantry had come IN three feSl-
ments of infantry, a battalion OF morse, ana
the cavalry Of hussars had arrived on the
fiftecth Another regiment was expected
on the following day.


The two Chambers of the Cortes were IN
session. A committee was appointed by the
Peers, to draw up an address TO the throhe'
requesting that pardons might be offered to
certain descriptions of rebels. The Count
Villa Flor was present, and OF course haa
absented himself from the army.


Private letters from Lisbon to the first OF
March, received by the Confucius, state po-
litical affairs were far from being settled, al
though 10 new occurrences of Importance
had transpred. The Anti ConstitutionaIiSts,
if nut down in one section Of the country,
suddenly appeared in other places III such
numbers and with such means, as could not
be accounted for on any other ground, than
that they were reinforced and furnished with
money by Spain or some other foreign pow
er. There was no doubt that large MAJOR
ity of the ignorant lower classes OF the For
tuguese population were taught to believe
that that they must oppose government which
would operate against the interests OF their
long established religion and habits. One
letter expresses belief that war must yet
be carried into Spsin. This was also the
opinion of the American consul, as we are IN
formed by capt. Riley. Captain X. under
stood that an engagement had taken plas e
between party of the royalists and one OF
the constitutionaiists, about the last OF teh-
ruary, near the frontiers Of Spain. III which
the former were again defeated.

l,be orcmarks and reply" which have been

correspondents will not observe moderation IN

correspondent, signing himself True
Bue," complains that there Is, Of late, a
crcat deal Of deception practiscd by young
men, towards unsuspccting females. That
crtain persons, after having IN most in
inuating manner secured the affections OF
females, for whom they had profcsscd
an ardent attachment-had suddenly ceased
their attentions, upon some frivolous pre-
t.xt--out in fact. merely to CRAFTY an inor-
hinatc self-love. which knows no other de-
sire than its own qualification. We believe
such characters are too numerous, and SUCH
conduct too frequently practised; but IL Is
not in our power, to detect the one or pre-
vent the other.--Yet, let the ladies OF oui
rood borough point out, to us, such con-
,emptiblc creature, ard for their sake wc
viii proclaim him in capitals as large as The
title line Of this paper. Let females DC Oh
their guard d-relinquish all desire to coque'
land when such "despisers Of fair ladies
love-" shall bc found among them, courtne
smiles to WIN their. tears. give the a
lam, and let him be hooted out OF their so
ciety

full articles.headline: FECuNnITY OE FISHES
full articles.article:
II is asserted Of the Herring that if suffered to
multiply unmolestcd, and its offspring to remain
undiminished during the space Of twenty years,
il would showa progeny many times greater IN
bulk than the whole earth! And that a single
Goldfish will produce at birth, if they escape
depreciation, a number equal to the whole pop
ulition OF Engand.

full articles.headline: ACTIVE BENEVOLENCE.
full articles.article:
A horse, harnessed to chaisc, was observed
during the greater part Of yesterday tied at the
lower end of Merchants Hall, says the Boston
Courier. Some pssser-by, more consideratc
than the owner Of the beast, towards night, plac-
ed on conspicuous part of the harness the fol-
lowing iabel-"Wunfed, half a peck of oats IL
1,iire Uithin"

among them. If we understand their plan
and object, they are humane and benevolent,
and we hope they may be successful. Those
tribes are good deal advanced in civillza-
tion, and are fast improving. The legslat-
i've system of the United States, adapted to
their condition, and applied with real dis
position to do them good, might be product.
i've of the highest benefits.

After the Goth MaYncxt, tic Saturday Herald,
printed at Baltimcrc, by Mi Samuel Sands, viii

merican, or Weekly Journal @. Politics, Science

The ".4riei, Q,H Ladies L,tefary Gasettc," n
se,ni-monthly publication, has just issued from
the Philadelphia press, published for the Editor
by ElwooJ Walter, No n, Markct.st.


The ARIEL is intended 10 be an interesting
and agreeable companion for tho Ladies, devot-
ed to Literature and the Arts containing sy-
nopsis of all that is passing in the polite, the
fashionable, and the literary world, with sum
mary of news. Original Essays, choice Tales,
select pieces Of Poctry sketches of female char
lctcr, and other pleasing matter will occupy its
pages.


The Editor promises that no labor or expense
| will be spared to make it cheap and valuable
yster in the hands ofhterary ladies'. Measures
have been taken to secure the best periodicals OF
the day, from which extracts, calculated to i'm
move the female mind, Will be freely taken He
is determined to make it acceptable TO the La
dies. the uncommonly low price at which it is
published one DOllar yearly, must place it with
in every ones reach.


sufficient patronage is extended, the Ariel
will be issued ,ceckty, at the end ofthrcc months,


The subscription is payable in advance, and
all letters must be post paid, and addressed to
Ellwool Walter, No. Il, Magket-st. Philadel'
pha, who is Agent for the Editor.


Any person who viii procure six subscribers
and remit the money, shall receive copy gratis,
for one year.

In Philadelphia on the 9th inst by the Rev.

SHAKESPEARE.--A dramatic process
sion is intended to be given on the next ami
versary OF the birth day of Shakespeare---
He was born April 23d, 1864. Grand pre-
para.ions are now making by the Shakes

peare society Of Stratford- on Avon, towards
celebration of the day and handsome
subscription has already been entered into
to defray incidental expences.

A lamp has been invented in England
which burns without a wick and is supplied
with oil, A capillary, or very small tube, is
supported perpendicularly in the oil, and on
being lighted, will burn with perfect rcgu-
larity until exhausted.

We have not, for long time. had spring
which promises as fruitful a year as the pre-
sent; and if the saying of our old men hold
good, the last cold winter is security that our
promises of rich harvest will not be ami
hilated by untimely frost According to a
crcditable old inliabitant of Saltzburgh it is
now near sixty years since the peach trees
were in bloom on the tenth of April.

large spots.

with three other persons, named Couts,

river near Steubenvclle, Ohio, the boat in
which they were, was capsized, and having
been loaded with sand, It Immediately sunk,
and all hands, with the exception of Mr..
Swords, was drowned.

on the evening of the .51th ult. while sitting
at home, in conversation with friend, aud |
in presence Of his wife. A part of the win
dow blind had been rc'uovcd short time
previously, and gun was fired through the !
window, which wounded him with about l59
small shot. He died in about 2l hours. a
man named Cameron has been arrested for
trial

sistance could be given that she survived
but few hours.

:. Some time since, MIR. Lundy, the editor 0
i the Genius of Universal Emancipation, ;
= weekly paper published in Baltimore, usct
